entities.text:
LLM Augmented LLMs: Expanding Capabilities through Composition

Proposes CALM, which introduces cross-attention between models to compose their representations and enable new capabilities
arxiv.org/abs/2401.02412

LLM Augmented LLMs

Yeah, you heard that right! This work explores composing existing foundation models with specific models to expand capabilities. 

Introduces cross-attention between models to compose representations that enable new capabilities. 

As an example, a PaLM2-S model was augmented with a smaller model trained on low-resource languages to improve English translation and arithmetic reasoning for low-resource languages. 

This was also done with a code-specific model which led to a 40% improvement over the base code model on code generation and explanation tasks. This is reported to be on par with fully fine-tuned counterparts. 

These results are exciting. Efficient use of existing LLMs offers an incredible opportunity such as effectively augmenting foundational models with proprietary models to extend capabilities such as reasoning, world knowledge, and more.
arxiv.org/abs/2401.02412

entities.text:
Google DeepMind announce LLM Augmented LLMs

Expanding Capabilities through Composition

paper page:
huggingface.co/papers/2401.02…

Foundational models with billions of parameters which have been trained on large corpora of data have demonstrated non-trivial skills in a variety of domains. However, due to their monolithic structure, it is challenging and expensive to augment them or impart new skills. On the other hand, due to their adaptation abilities, several new instances of these models are being trained towards new domains and tasks. In this work, we study the problem of efficient and practical composition of existing foundation models with more specific models to enable newer capabilities. To this end, we propose CALM -- Composition to Augment Language Models -- which introduces cross-attention between models to compose their representations and enable new capabilities. Salient features of CALM are: (i) Scales up LLMs on new tasks by 're-using' existing LLMs along with a few additional parameters and data, (ii) Existing model weights are kept intact, and hence preserves existing capabilities, and (iii) Applies to diverse domains and settings. We illustrate that augmenting PaLM2-S with a smaller model trained on low-resource languages results in an absolute improvement of up to 13\% on tasks like translation into English and arithmetic reasoning for low-resource languages. Similarly, when PaLM2-S is augmented with a code-specific model, we see a relative improvement of 40\% over the base model for code generation and explanation tasks -- on-par with fully fine-tuned counterparts.

entities.text:
Googleの研究者らが、あるタスクに強いLLMを使って別のLLMを同タスクに強くするためのフレームワークを開発したと報告しています。

名称は『CALM（Composition to Augment Language Models）』です。

"LLM Augmented LLMs: Expanding Capabilities through Composition"より

■フレームワークの全容
1. 特定のタスクに強いLLMを用意
2. 訓練したいLLMを用意
3. 両者をクロスアテンション層で連携
4. LLM間の情報共有を行う
5. 評価を行う

■メリット
- 特定タスクに強いLLMは小型で良い
- 既存スキルは保持できる
- 低コスト、高効率である

■実験結果
- 訓練後モデルの性能が向上した
- 小さなモデルでも成果が出た
- 既存の方法より小リソースで実現した

なお、本手法の有効性は今後さまざまなベンチマークで確かめていきたいと述べられています。
また、有効性のあるLLMペアを整理する必要があるかもしれないとのことです。

entities.text:
Extending an LLM for new knowledge sources is tedious—fine-tuning is expensive/causes forgetting, LoRA is restrictive.

Excited to share our work where we show that an LLM can be efficiently *composed* with specialized (L)LMs to enable new tasks!
arxiv.org/abs/2401.02412

mediaDetails.ext_alt_text:
The title of our paper: "LLM Augmented LLMs: Expanding Capabilities through Composition". All authors: "Rachit Bansal, Bidisha Samanta, Siddharth Dalmia, Nitish Gupta, Shikhar Vashishth, Sriram Ganapathy, Abhishek Bapna, Prateek Jain, Partha Talukdar", and their affiliations: Google Research, India and Google DeepMind.

Figure shows an overview of our framework: To augment an anchor LLM (mB) with new capabilities through composition with a specialized augmenting model (mA). Figure illustrates three mA with different
capabilities: key-value mapping (left), low-resource languages (center), and code (right). Models mA and mB remain unchanged during composition. A few additional parameters are learnt over models’ layer representations.

user.name: Rachit Bansal
user.description: CS PhD @Harvard • Pre-doc @GoogleDeepMind • Anything `science', ~cosmos, and Oxford commas

entities.text:
Consider a toy example:

You have some key-value pairs {x1: 10, x2: 7,..., xn: 2} to reason upon.
You have an LLM that excels at reasoning but has no knowledge of the KV pairs.

Composing a model trained on the pairs with the LLM enables reasoning over the pairs (x1+x8*xn = 38)!

mediaDetails.ext_alt_text: An overview of our key-value task along with a table that shows the results. Evaluation (accuracy (%)) for a synthetic key-value (KV) task. mA is trained to memorize the KV mappings while mB excels at arithmetic We see that a composition mA⊕B is able to perform arithmetic over held-out keys.

user.name: Rachit Bansal
user.description: CS PhD @Harvard • Pre-doc @GoogleDeepMind • Anything `science', ~cosmos, and Oxford commas

entities.text:
Rather than a shallow combination, CALM introduces a small set of cross-attention parameters over models’ layer representations.

CALM finds an effective combination of models, *enabling* new tasks that neither of the models could do, while preserving their original capabilities!

user.name: Rachit Bansal
user.description: CS PhD @Harvard • Pre-doc @GoogleDeepMind • Anything `science', ~cosmos, and Oxford commas

entities.text:
We explore CALM for real-world tasks:

Multilinguality:
We reuse an LM trained on a bunch of low-resource languages (LRLs)
w/ an LLM that has never seen some of these LRLs.

We see promising results for MT & reasoning across all L- and H-RLs (unlike FT that leads to forgetting)!

mediaDetails.ext_alt_text: An overview of CALM for multilinguality. Results show the gains seen by the composed model mA⊕B over the anchor model, mB, for the complete set of FLORES-200 languages. The languages are sorted from low to high-resource.

user.name: Rachit Bansal
user.description: CS PhD @Harvard • Pre-doc @GoogleDeepMind • Anything `science', ~cosmos, and Oxford commas

entities.text:
Coding:
We compose an LM trained on the entire set of open-source GitHub code
w/ an LLM where code is under-represented in its training data.

We see significant gains across all tasks: Code explanation (CodeXGLUE), completion (HumanEval), and generation (MBPP). Again, unlike FT.

mediaDetails.ext_alt_text:
Results of CALM for coding evaluations. Evaluations for code generation and understanding across three tasks: Code Completion
(CC), Text-to-Code (T2C), and Code-to-Text (C2T). Augmenting code understanding to mB using mA significantly improves performances across all datasets. mCode B represents a skyline where mB further pretrained on the DCode, which shows catastrophic forgetting of text generation task.

user.name: Rachit Bansal
user.description: CS PhD @Harvard • Pre-doc @GoogleDeepMind • Anything `science', ~cosmos, and Oxford commas

entities.text:
We are especially excited about the potential of this work in enabling collaborative development of large models in a modular manner.

People across the community could develop small specialized models for their languages/domains/etc., and see them work w/ capabilities of an LLM.

user.name: Pengming Wang
user.description: Founding team @poolsideai | prev @DeepMind, PhD @Cambridge_Uni, FunSearch co-author

entities.text:
[CL] LLM Augmented LLMs: Expanding Capabilities through Composition
R Bansal, B Samanta, S Dalmia, N Gupta, S Vashishth, S Ganapathy, A Bapna, P Jain, P Talukdar [Google Research & Google DeepMind] (2024)
arxiv.org/abs/2401.02412

- LLMs are monolithic, making augmenting or imparting new skills challenging and expensive. Many domain-specific LLMs are being trained, raising the question of composing them.

- Typical approaches like further pretraining or finetuning have downsides like requiring original training data. 

- CALM composes anchor and augmenting LLM by introducing cross-attention over their layer representations, keeping base model weights frozen.

- CALM applies to diverse domains, scales up LLMs by reusing models, and avoids catastrophic forgetting.

- Composing a low-resource language model with PaLM-S improves translation and reasoning for low-resource languages.

- Composing a code model with PaLM-S significantly improves code generation/understanding, on par with full finetuning. 

- CALM outperforms parameter efficient finetuning like LoRA, and is more effective than ablations like using vanilla augmenting model.

- Surprisingly, using augmenting model just as encoder significantly underperforms iterative decoding.

- CALM provides a practical way to reuse existing models without changing or retraining them.

mediaDetails.ext_alt_text: 大規模なデータ・コーパスで訓練された数十億のパラメータを持つ基礎モデルは、さまざまな領域で自明ではない能力を発揮している。しかし、一枚岩の構造であるため、その補強や新しいスキルの習得には困難とコストがかかる。その一方で、その適応能力のおかげで、これらのモデルの新しいインスタンスが、新しいドメインやタスクに向けていくつか訓練されている。この研究では、より新しい機能を実現するために、既存の基礎モデルとより特殊なモデルとの効率的かつ実用的な合成の問題を研究する。この目的のために、我々はCALM -- Composition to Augment Language Models -- を提案する。CALMは、モデル間のクロスアテンションを導入することで、それらの表現を合成し、新たな機能を実現する。CALMの主な特徴は以下の通りである：(i) 既存のLLMを「再利用」し、いくつかのパラメータとデータを追加することで、新しいタスクでLLMをスケールアップする、(ii)既存のモデルのウェイトがそのまま維持され、既存の能力が維持される。(iii) 多様な領域や環境に適用できる。PaLM2-Sを低リソース言語で訓練されたより小さなモデルで補強することで、低リソース言語の英語への翻訳や...

user.name: Prateek Jain
user.description: Learning machine learning at Google DeepMind.

entities.text: Key idea: a tandem of a primary and  a secondary model, where the secondary model uses representations of the primary model to generate responses. Gives a  better model than the secondary model (+14pts on TydiQA)  while being significantly faster than the primary model. [2/n]

user.name: Prateek Jain
user.description: Learning machine learning at Google DeepMind.

entities.text: Interestingly, Tandem can be combined with Speculative Decoding (SPEED) and Distill-Spec. This ensures that the output  matches that of the primary model but at a significant speed-up over  SPEED and Distill-Spec (up to ~1.17x on TPUv5e). [3/n]

user.name: Prateek Jain
user.description: Learning machine learning at Google DeepMind.

entities.text: So, how does it differ from many recent parallel and speculative decoding  approaches. Generally these approaches speculate about response tokens by using additional parallel or autoregressive heads on  top of the primary model. [4/n]

user.name: Prateek Jain
user.description: Learning machine learning at Google DeepMind.

entities.text: Tandem is — to the best of our knowledge — the only technique that utilizes attention mechanism to transfer knowledge of the large model to the small model, and that too with a flexible framework where any primary and secondary models can be used in Tandem. [5/n]

user.name: Prateek Jain
user.description: Learning machine learning at Google DeepMind.

entities.text: Bonus marks for recognizing that Tandem and CALM (
arxiv.org/abs/2401.02412
) are dual versions where Tandem uses a secondary model to generate response faster, while CALM uses a secondary model to augment capabilities of the primary model!

mediaDetails.ext_alt_text:
Abstract

This paper will look at the various predictions that have been made about AI and pro-pose decomposition schemas for analyzing them. It will propose a variety of theoretical tools for analyzing, judging, and improving these predictions. Focusing specifically on timeline predictions (dates given by which we should expect the creation of AI), it will show that there are strong theoretical grounds to expect predictions to be quite poor in this area. Using a database of 95 AI timeline predictions, it will show that these expectations are borne out in practice: expert predictions contradict each other considerably,
and are indistinguishable from non-expert predictions and past failed predictions. Predictions that AI lie 15 to 25 years in the future are the most common, from experts and non-experts alike.

entities.text:
isn't generality and human's learning capability two totally different things? I am not even sure that generality can be tied down to humans?

For e.g., two pieces of matter cannot occupy the same space.. general knowledge.. 

There are many such general knowledge puts limits to our intelligence & over this foundation our intelligence is built.. vary this & you get different sets of intelligence?

e.g.,.. the general knowledge is I jump I'll fall down (a general knowledge possessed by all living beings).. 

this implies there is a top & a down is also an intelligence (possessed by all living beings)

this implies there is a force acting on us (again possessed by all living beings)

But, 
* things come down because there is gravity is human defined explanation
* because of this force, matter cannot fly, is human defined understanding, this is not learning.. it is a definition of a constraint of the environment
* because there is gravity I have to do x,y,z to get matter to fly is human defined steps to solve the problem as seen by humans (this is experimenting, learning & defining & is intelligence isn't?)

But, all three of the above are conclusions from a single general knowledge.. there can be infinite potential parameters that are varied based on which these can take different forms of intelligence?

The point is how did that general knowledge form? Isn't it just a common set of principles that everyone agreed to be limited by?

So, shouldn't AGI be similar.. rather than trying to force AGI to follow human general knowledge / intelligence /... build it so that for its given data environment it comes up with a set of general rules & bases intelligence off that general rules.. shouldn't that be the basis of AGI?

Subsequent to that, we can constrain the general rules to follow the general rules of our space/time..

Faster processing will allow models to handle real time interactions more efficiently, while synthetic data generation could provide massive realistic datasets to train navigation without relying only on real time input

entities.text:
My little prediction of 2025: As AI scaling is plateauing (steady amazing progress like microprocessors vs jumps), we'll begin to see more of a focus on products.

Instead of a multi-modal architecture, there will be a focus on a multi-model architectures: how do we jointly train and integrate the AI models to work together to maximize perf while updating the models quickly.

I would expect to see every major industry get targeted (already happening): AI graphic designer, AI programmer, AI lawyer, AI doctor, AI chip designer, AI FP&A, etc.

The AI labs will have to cut burn and finally ask themselves: who is this for? why do they want it?

Introduction: <1743409814557143507> suggested benchmarking CALM against simple model merging. <1743500083889369114> supported this suggestion.

<1743570160307568892> explained the difficulties of merging models with different sizes and expressed doubts about merging's effectiveness for tasks where neither individual model performs well. They also mentioned exploring approximation methods.
<1743634954788192498> proposed growing the smaller transformer to match the larger one's size as a potential solution for merging.
Other users discussed related merging techniques and relevant papers.
Related works: <1743108438048272599> questioned the advantages of the proposed method compared to Mixture of Experts (MoEs).
Learning to compose (\u03b8 c ): <1743397126472610132> inquired about the experiment results with larger models and the number of parameters introduced by the "glue" layers.
Experiments: <1743499568736776391> inquired about the memory implications of the proposed method.

Introduction: <1743316756649652389> suggests that the CALM method could significantly benefit Bittensor and $TAO by enabling seamless integration of various AI models, enhancing their intelligence and expanding their capabilities without requiring a complete rebuild. <1743403674292924620> agrees with this assessment.
Related works: <1743970879774617710> questions the novelty of CALM, citing similarities with existing ML model routing and semantic routing techniques like Nvidia Nemo Guardrails.
Composition to augment language models (: <1743901380396380395> suggested combining models trained for different language levels to test the proposed approach.

Related works: <1744045064219709455> suggested that Reexpress complements the paper's focus on LLM composition by providing a practical tool for combining multiple LLMs for classification and verification tasks without coding.

<1744581426912301322> highlighted SN-Netv2 [[arxiv.org/abs/2307.00154]], which composes smaller vision transformers with larger ones, mirroring CALM's approach but in the visual domain, offering a cross-modal perspective on compositional architectures.

<1857018107425968263> shared a paper [[arxiv.org/abs/2401.02412]] that appears to align with <1856728723858554937>'s prediction of a shift towards multi-model architectures, potentially providing further context for CALM's contribution to this emerging trend.

Q&A.Introduction: The authors propose CALM, a framework for composing large language models (LLMs) without altering their weights, to enable new capabilities by combining existing models' strengths. This addresses the limitations of existing methods like routing and merging, especially when dealing with models of varying sizes and training objectives.
Q&A.Related works: The authors discuss existing methods for adapting large language models (LLMs), including parameter-efficient fine-tuning and model merging, highlighting their limitations compared to their proposed method (CALM). CALM allows adaptation to new domains and is more generally applicable to different models.
Q&A.Learning to compose (\u03b8 c ): The authors propose a method to compose two large language models (LLMs) by connecting a subset of layers from each model.  They introduce cross-attention and projection layers to align and integrate the representations from the two models.
Q&A.Experiments: The authors propose composing a large language model (LLM) with smaller, specialized LLMs to enhance its capabilities in specific domains like arithmetic, low-resource language translation, and code completion.  They use a frozen, pre-trained PaLM2 model as the anchor LLM.

Perspective.Introduction: The authors propose CALM, a framework for composing large language models (LLMs) to combine their capabilities without retraining.  This allows an anchor LLM to leverage the specialized skills of an augmenting model, addressing challenges like computational cost and data privacy. CALM uses a small number of trainable parameters over the models' intermediate layer representations to find an effective combination.
Perspective.Related works: The authors propose CALM, a method for augmenting LLMs. They compare CALM to existing techniques like parameter-efficient fine-tuning (e.g., LoRA), model merging, and model/task compositionality, highlighting CALM's advantages in adaptability and generality.
Perspective.Composition to augment language models (: The authors propose Composition to Augment Language Models (CALM), a method to compose two language models with frozen weights, a base model and an augmenting model, to enable new capabilities.  A few examples from the target composition domain are used to learn the composition.
